options.content:
# Data from Beacon node

From a standard lighthouse beacon client, we can collect information like: epoch, headslot, and peer connection on the networking layer.

panels.title: Data collected from beacon node
Vanilla Lighthouse beacon

panels.description: Collect peers and their associated multiaddresses from libp2p layer, extracted from `peer-manager` of `lighthouse_network` crate
panels.title: Peer ID to multiaddress
Current beacon epoch
Current head slot
Modified "Metaclear" Lighhouse beacon

panels.description: Table on the right shows the association of validators' public key and IP addresses. This data can be obtained by running a CL.

options.content:
Previously, HOPR team conducted research on “validator sniping”, a technique where attackers exploit the Proof-of-Stake (PoS) protocol to steal block rewards from validators.

This attack takes advantage of the fact that both validators' public keys and IP addresses are publicly known.

You can read more about our findings in our blog post: "Proof-of-Stake Validator Sniping Research".


Source: https://medium.com/hoprnet/proof-of-stake-validator-sniping-research-8670c4a88a1c

panels.title: Knowing validators' public keys and IP addresses

panels.description: Associating validators' public keys with peer IDs by observing attestations.
panels.title: Peer ID and pubkey from attestations

panels.description: By observing as many attestations as possible, the node can reliably associate a public key with its multiaddress. Below is the most likely association.
panels.title: From pubkey to CL multiaddress
Modified "Metaclear" relayer

panels.description: The modified `flashbot/mev-relay` implementation extracts metadata of http requests sent to the relayer.

options.content:
"Meta-clear" MEV Relay

The modified `flashbot/mev-relay` implementation extracts metadata of http requests sent to the relayer, particularly on the following endpoints:

On the validators side:
  • POST /eth/v1/builder/blinded_blocks
  • GET /eth/v1/builder/header/{slot}/{parent_hash}/{pubkey}
  • POST /eth/v1/builder/validators
On the block builders side:
  • POST /relay/v1/builder/blocks
  • GET /relay/v1/builder/validators

panels.title: "Meta-clear" MEV Relay

panels.description: Number of http requests per mev-relayer endpoint
panels.title: MEV-Relayer http endpoint requests [per min]

panels.description: All the validators registered to the current mev-relayer

targets.rawSql:
SELECT pubkey, CONCAT(ip, ':', port) AS mev_boost_ip, validators.inserted_at as registration_timestamp FROM custom_validator_registration validators
LEFT JOIN
custom_metadata metadata
ON metadata.key=validators.pubkey

panels.title: Registered validators
Attacking next epoch

targets.rawSql:
SELECT slot, (slot/32 + 1) as epoch, validator_index, proposer_pubkey FROM custom_proposer_duties 
ORDER BY slot DESC
LIMIT 64

panels.title: Proposer of the current and next epoches

targets.rawSql:
WITH validator_metadata AS (
  SELECT pubkey, CONCAT(ip, ':', port) AS mev_boost_ip, metadata.inserted_at AS request_timestamp FROM custom_validator_registration validators
  LEFT JOIN
  custom_metadata metadata
  ON metadata.key=validators.pubkey
), next_epoch_proposers AS (
  SELECT slot, slot/32 as epoch, validator_index, proposer_pubkey FROM custom_proposer_duties 
  ORDER BY slot DESC
  LIMIT 32
)

SELECT slot, epoch, validator_index, proposer_pubkey, mev_boost_ip FROM next_epoch_proposers
LEFT JOIN validator_metadata
ON validator_metadata.pubkey = next_epoch_proposers.proposer_pubkey

panels.title: Who to attack in the next 12ish min

targets.rawSql:
SELECT slot, prev_randao, parent_hash, inserted_at FROM custom_payload_attributes
ORDER BY slot DESC
LIMIT 50
